title: Buddhist Priest's Robe (Kesa) with Stylized Floral and Lozenge Decor
description: A Buddhist priest's robe known in Japan as a kesa (Sanskrit, kasaya), this rectangular garment is made up of mulitple pieces of the same cloth that together form a unified assemblage of columns and rectangles framed within a border. The basic fabric is a green silk decorated with an all-over design of multicolored lozenges (rhombuses) punctuated with large flowers, probably chrysanthemums, applied or embroidered onto the surface in gold.
creditline: Harvard Art Museums/Arthur M. Sackler Museum, The Louis V. Ledoux Collection; Gift of Mrs. L. Pierre Ledoux in memory of her husband
medium: Compound-weave silk with patterning in supplementary wefts; selected motifs embroidered with gold and polychrome silk threads
provenance:
Nishi Hongwangi, 1910. [Roland Koscherak, NY, by 1939], sold; to Louis V. Ledoux Collection, New York (1939- 1948), by descent; to his son L. Pierre Ledoux, New York (1948-2001), by inheritance; to his widow Joan F. Ledoux, New York, (2001-2013), gift; to Harvard Art Museums, 2013.
